item.title: Trump Rescinds Canada’s Invitation to Join His ‘Board of Peace’
item.description: The president appeared to be lashing out in response to stark, high-profile remarks by Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada that rejected Mr. Trump’s efforts to dismantle the international order.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

item.title: Mark Carney Says Firmly That ‘Canada Doesn’t Live Because of the United States’
item.description: The Canadian prime minister spoke after returning from the World Economic Forum where he urged middle powers to team up in resisting President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada at a news conference in Quebec City on Thursday.

item.title: Venezuela’s Edmundo González Said His Son-in-Law Was Freed From Detention
item.description: Edmundo González, seen by many as the real winner of Venezuela’s 2024 election, said his son-in-law was released after more than a year in detention.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Mariana González de Tudares, right, daughter of the former Venezuelan presidential candidate Edmundo González, waiting this month outside a detention center in Caracas, Venezuela.

item.title: Tânia Maria Is Brazil’s Newest Film Icon
item.description: Clad in florals and puffing on a cigarette, Tânia Maria has captivated audiences with a striking, if brief, performance in “The Secret Agent,” Brazil’s latest Oscar nominee.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tânia Maria, with Wagner Moura in a scene from “The Secret Agent,” has drawn praise from international critics.

item.title: Majority of Latin Americans Endorsed Trump’s Intervention In Venezuela, Polls Show
item.description: A majority of those surveyed said they support the intervention, suggesting a shift from ideology to pragmatism, at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Celebrations in Buenos Aires after the U.S. capture of Nicolás Maduro, the Venezuelan president, this month.

item.title: After Maduro’s Last Dance, a New Rhythm Goes Viral in Venezuela
item.description: For years, Nicolás Maduro and his movement used song and dance to rally support. Now, millions of Venezuelans are dancing to a different political tune.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, dancing during “Venezuelan Student Day” in November.

item.title: Pressured by Trump, Mexico Sends 37 Accused Criminals to U.S.
item.description: Mexico has sought to do more to combat its cartels in an effort to stave off airstrikes threatened by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mexican police officers at a crime scene in Culiacán, the home territory of the Sinaloa cartel, in 2024.

item.title: Carney Speech on U.S. ‘Rupture’ and Canada’s Survival Draws Standing Ovation at Davos
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney got a standing ovation in Davos for starkly describing the end of Pax Americana. He is looking for new allies to help his country survive it.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Ian Austen

item.title: C.I.A.’s New Focus on Latin America Reflected in Raid to Seize Maduro
item.description: A senior U.S. official declined to confirm the specific operations in Venezuela, but said a covert team provided real-time support for the military.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Tyler Pager
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A member of Venezuela’s National Guard at the entrance to the country’s largest military complex in Caracas, the capital, after President Nicolás Maduro’s capture on Jan. 3.

item.title: The Northern Lights Have Inspired Humans for Thousands of Years
item.description: The aurora borealis has animated myths, art, poetry and music for thousands of years. Here are some examples.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Heritage Art/Heritage Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: “Aurora Borealis,” an 1865 painting by the American landscape painter Frederic Edwin Church.

item.title: A Venezuelan Political Prisoner Finally Comes Home
item.description: Ángel Godoy was thrown into jail after writing columns that angered the government of President Nicolás Maduro. Now his family is trying to make up for lost time.
item.dc:creator: Alejandro Cegarra, Isayen Herrera and James Wagner
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ángel Godoy embracing his wife, Adriana Briceño, after arriving at home for the first time after spending a year in jail.

item.title: How Trump Flexes Power in White House Meetings With Zelensky and Others
item.description: With cameras rolling, President Trump met with more than 40 international leaders in his first year back in office.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater

item.title: Death Toll Rises in Guatemalan Gang Riots
item.description: Uprisings in three prisons have killed 10 police officers, presenting another challenge for President Bernardo Arévalo in his fight against corruption and organized crime.
item.dc:creator: Jody García, James Wagner and Daniele Volpe
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ceremony to honor eight police officers who died in attacks by gang members the day before, on Monday in Guatemala City.

item.title: Splits Emerge Among Venezuelans as Revolutionary Dream Fades
item.description: Supporters of former president Hugo Chávez, the anti-American socialist, are struggling to come to terms with their government’s pact with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: Demonstrators demanding the release of President Nicolás Maduro in Caracas, Venezuela, on Friday.

item.title: What to Know About Hezbollah’s Ties to Venezuela
item.description: U.S. authorities have accused Hezbollah of complicity in drug trafficking and money laundering schemes in Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah fighters at the Lebanon-Syria border in 2017.

item.title: Guatemala Declares State of Emergency to Address Gang Violence
item.description: The country has seen a surge of unrest in recent days, including uprisings at prisons and the killing of police officers, which the authorities have blamed on gangs.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Guatemalan riot police officers guard the entrance to the men’s Preventive Detention Center in Guatemala City on Sunday.

item.title: Chile Wildfires Kill 16 and Force Wide Evacuation
item.description: One mayor pleaded with the national government for help as flames destroyed entire neighborhoods in the southern region of Biobío.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and John Bartlett
item.media:description: Buildings damaged by wildfires in Chile’s Biobío region on Sunday.

item.title: The Biggest Challenge in Venezuela Is Soaring Food Prices
item.description: Economic instability in Venezuela after the U.S. raid to capture its president is deepening inflation and rattling the currency, sending grocery bills soaring for millions of people.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova, Camille Rodríguez Montilla and Isayen Herrera
item.media:description: A woman showing her nearly empty refrigerator in Los Teques, Venezuela.

item.title: Mr. Carney Goes to Beijing
item.description: The trip, a whirlwind of meetings with Chinese industry and top government officials, conveyed how the prime minister is viewing the wider world.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney with Xi Jinping, China’s top leader.

item.title: Can Cuba Survive Without Venezuela’s Oil?
item.description: President Trump stopped Venezuelan oil shipments to Cuba, and experts say disaster looms. Oil fuels its electric grid and without alternative supplies the country will plunge into extended darkness.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:description: A Cuban-flagged oil tanker anchored near the Matanzas terminal this month in Cuba.

item.title: Trump Has Machado’s Nobel Prize, but Neither Got What They Really Wanted
item.description: President Trump has María Corina Machado’s medal, but he is not recognized as the prize laureate. Ms. Machado did not win Mr. Trump’s endorsement to become Venezuela’s president.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado’s decision to present her Nobel Peace Prize medal to President Trump has been met with mixed reviews in the United States and abroad.

item.title: Judge Recommends U.S. Issue Visa to Student Who Was Deported in Error
item.description: A federal prosecutor apologized this week, saying an ICE officer made a “mistake” in deporting Any Lucia López Belloza, a college freshman in Massachusetts, to Honduras.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Any Lucia Lopez Belloza's attorney, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Any Lucia López Belloza celebrating her high school graduation in Texas last year. She was attending college in Massachusetts before her deportation in November.

item.title: Julio Iglesias Denies Sexual Abuse Claims by Former Employees
item.description: The singer called the accusations “completely false” in a statement released after Spanish prosecutors said they would investigate.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:description: Julio Iglesias in 2016, when a star bearing his name was unveiled in San Juan, P.R.

item.title: C.I.A. Director Meets With Venezuela’s Interim President in Caracas
item.description: The high-profile visit, which could be seen as snubbing the opposition, comes nearly two weeks after the U.S. military seized President Nicolás Maduro in a raid.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: John Ratcliffe, the C.I.A. director, at the U.S. Capitol last week. On Thursday, he met with Delcy Rodríguez, the interim president of Venezuela, and delivered a message of cooperation.

item.title: After Trump Call, Colombia’s Petro Turns Up Heat on Far-Left Armed Group
item.description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia is taking a harder line against the National Liberation Army, or ELN, a leftist group experts call a powerful drug trafficker in Colombia and Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Genevieve Glatsky and Max Bearak
item.media:description: National Liberation Army, or ELN, rebels in the Catatumbo region of Colombia last year.

item.title: Canada Strikes Tariffs Deal With China, as Carney Looks to Diversify From U.S.
item.description: China will in turn cut its own tariffs on Canadian canola products, Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada said in Beijing on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada meeting on Friday with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

item.title: Trump Chooses Venezuela’s Oil Over Democracy
item.description: Two conversations this week confirmed that President Trump backs the remnants of Nicolás Maduro’s regime over the Venezuelan opposition seeking to hold elections.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, the interim president of Venezuela, moments before her swearing-in in Caracas, the country’s capital, in January.
